Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2015 07:56PM Ariom wrote: Donna Dew, I have the same experience as you with the "Dog Ear", mine hurt, zapped and zinged, got caught in my bra and snuck out over the side of my bra. I hated that sucker, but at first, I didn't want any more surgery so I put up with it for over a year. Finally, I spoke with my surgeon about it, he wanted me to go to hospital and have another general anesthetic. He said it would be like doing another mini Mx. I told him I wasn't interested in having another general, could he please do it with a local anesthetic, the area around it was all numb anyway. He finally, reluctantly agreed and I had it done in his office. The first he's ever done that way. It wouldn't be for everyone, but for me, it was the best thing I could have done. We chatted through the whole procedure and he even took pictures for me. I think he enjoyed it. LOL If you can take looking at the pictures of the transition from Mx through to the removal of the Dog Ear, there are pictures on Erica's site breastfree.org, I am willing to bet, you will be surprised by the difference. For those who haven't experienced that annoyance, it probably doesn't look like much, but for us, it is such a relief. Now, after more time has elapsed, you can't really see where the scar is at all. You may even consider having the revision done during the other surgery. I just wanted to let you know that you don't have to put up with the discomfort, it is able to be fixed. We look forward to getting to know you too! There are lots of us who haven't reconstructed and there is a lot of information on boobs, foobs and prosthesis and bras and clothing with pockets too. Your link is very interesting, the bras are really pretty. I have never been to Canada, but many years ago I was working in the music business, at a booking agency and we were looking after a group from Canada who were touring here, called Guess Who. I remember one of the members was from Saskatchewen, he talked a lot about his home. Then in the 90's I worked for an American airline, here in Australia and we ground handled Air Canada, so I met lots and lots of lovely Canadians, some from Saskachewen too and there were a few things I could talk to them about that I learned from that contact so long ago. I wish you all the very best...let us know how you're doing.

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2013 02:59PM Ariom wrote: Hi Misha! That sounds really gorgeous! Just like mine! LOL I am sure that mine started when I had my Stereotactic Core Biopsy, and then worsened when I had the Mx. There is so much controversy about Mondors, Lymph Cording, and Thrombosis. I have read everything I can find on it, but I think that due to the fact that it "resolves itself", no one bothers too much about it. Personally, I really didn't like having, what I equated to a nasty varicose vein, that branched off down my abdomen. It looked nasty, and when it was massaged it felt really yuck too. I don't believe that mine had any Lymph involvement either, but I did read that when some of these things have been biopsied, they can be either lymph or vein. It is also quite common, I believe, in women who have had breast augmentation, so that means that the description of it being caused by any kind of trauma to the breast. sounds spot on.  Good Luck with it Misha, I hope it resolves quickly for you.

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2014 12:38AM Ariom wrote: Hi scary, I just had my very similar sounding appendage removed, a few weeks ago. My Surgeon explained that it was just flesh that was always pulled forward by the weight of the breast and after the breast was gone it just sits under the arm. Mine felt like it had a bunch of cut nerves in it, so when I stretched my arm up and it slipped over the side of my bra, the sensation was a zinger. I had actually started to develop a habit of always feeling for it to make sure it was tucked in, yuck!  I couldn't be happier with the results of the revision. I had it done under a local anesthetic in my Surgeons office. Not really what he wanted to do, but I just didn't want another General Anesthetic. It is now a nice flat area without the zinging, quite numb, but so much better than it was. It has added about 7cm to the Mx scar, but it is so fine, it won't be too visible.  I have heard of these things being removed during reconstruction. Good luck with it!

Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2013 04:19AM Ariom wrote: All the very best to both of you! It's a terribly stressful time, we, as humans don't do fear of the unknown very well.  Microcalcifications are very common, it is when they form a pattern that DCIS is suspected and biopsy is the only way to get a difinitive answer. As you know, 80% of these biopsies return a B9 finding. That's what I am hoping for both of you. Try to take it easy and take some big cleansing breaths. You'll do just fine. I had a Stereotactic Biopsy, and actually found it really interesting. No pain during the test, just a bit of bruising the following day. They will give you a little frozen pad to put in your bra, it really helps.  Let us know how you do, everyone here understands just what you're going through. The waiting is just awful. Take care!

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2015 11:57PM Ariom wrote: Hello Donna-Dew, Welcome to BCO. I am so sorry to hear how this has panned out for you. Firstly, there are many of us here, who have been Dx with DCIS, some with another Dx like you and there is a lot of very interesting information about both DCIS and about reducing stress and how to alter our lifestyle if that is something we want to explore. Please don't beat yourself up and feel guilty about what you maybe, should'a, could'a, done to prevent this, there are no guarantees. There are many, many women here who have lived the lifestyle you mention and have still ended up here. Absolutely, trying to cut down on stress, eat healthy and exercise is a great and positive lifestyle change to aim for, but truly, leave the past in the past and move forward and be kind to yourself:) I was Dx with high grade DCIS in 2012. I decided to have a Umx and SNB, no recon, but never considered removing both breasts.It was simply that in good conscience, I couldn't remove a healthy body part. I figured, if there was going to be an issue with my other breast, I would handle it if I had to an I would certainly have another Mx in a heartbeat, if there was any hint, of a repeat performance! I have 6 monthly checks with my Surgeon and annual mammos and u/s. For me, the transition has been easy, I don't have an issue with being a Uni and wearing a form, is just part of what I do now. I wish you all the very best and hope you will stay on the boards, chat to others who will share their experiences and let us know how you get on. Hugs to you!

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2013 12:10AM Ariom wrote: I have to agree with Blessings and Lago. I have been using massage on my Mx scar and it has really responded well. I have ordered scar away strips too. I have used them on other scars and found them to work really well. When you say you had thrombosis, was that Mondors Cording? I had cording that ran down from where my nipple would have been, across my abdomen and then split off like  tree, down from my ribs. It was explained to me as a thrombosis, or phlebitis. Also, it has been described as a crossover to axillary cording which is in the lymph system. Some people get both. UUUgghhh! The reason I ask you, is that massage got rid of mine. If I were you, I'd ask your Surgeon, and if that is what you have, and if he/she recommends massage I'd strongly advise you to try it. It took a few weeks, but it has completely resolved it for me. Good Luck, and take care!

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2015 03:18AM Ariom wrote: Hi tangeriinequeen, although I didn't have a prophy Mx, I was in a similar position, in that my Surgeon was concerned that there may have been an invasive component to my DCIS, so he told me that he couldn't in all good conscience, not do a SNB with my Umx. He explained that taking one node was better than risking having to do an Axillary clearance, if the final pathology came back with surprise in it. Once the breast is gone, there is no way to find the sentinel node. I weighed it up and decided he was right. When it comes to the radioactive dye etc, unfortunately, it is the only way to do these tests and the amount used is miniscule. I wish you all the best with your decision, let us know how you get on.

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2013 12:50AM - edited Jun 27, 2013 12:51AM by Ariom I am so sorry to hear what you are going through. I just wanted to jump in and say that the feeling you have in the underarm, and the Bingo Fat(I love that description) is exactly what you would expect fron removal of a lymph node.  They are nasty little devils when removed, and give a lot of us what I call "The Claw". It is a burning, grasping, numbness that can go right down your arm. Very unpleasant! As for the IBC, it is a rare one, I am not saying don't follow it up. I would definitely be pushing for the punch biopsies too. You are NOT a hypochondriac, don't let them make you feel bad about being your own advocate. We have to follow our intuition, lets just hope you are wrong, and it is a bad case of Mastitis, or indeed an infection from the previous procedure. I find if I am not getting what I want from Doctors, I ask them how they will feel if I am right and they missed it! It usually gets action. I sure hope this is resolved for you soon. I can imagine how terrible you are feeling, and I know the waiting is just brutal, we all know that feeling. ((((Hugs))))) to you, I hope you get answers soon, Let us know how you get on!

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2013 10:50PM Ariom wrote: Hi Spiritdeep, They leave th elittle titanium clip inside to mark the area for further imaging or if you have surgery to remove the area. I don't think there is anything untoward by them letting you know there may be more imaging. When I went back for my callback after a suspicious finding on a regular mammo, they said they would give me another mammo, if still unsure they would give me an ultrasound, then if still unsure a Fine Needle Aspiration, and finally if they were still not happy it would be a Core Biopsy. I had the mammo, and then straight to Core Biopsy. I was afraid that this jump to the Core Biopsy meant that it was really serious, but I was wrong, it was just that Core Biopsy was required for DCIS which is what they thought I had. I had a clip inserted too, they showed it to me on the screen, along with all the material they took during the Core Biopsy. The team I had were fantastic, talking me through every step. I didn't have any sedation nor did I feel any claustraphobia from the Core Biopsy. Try not to read too much into what is happening right now. After you have met with them and the results are in you will have a clear picture.   Everyone will tell you that the fear of the unknown, and the waiting is the worst part this journey. Take care and let us know how you do! Hoping for a great outcome for you!
Posts.Title: Instructions for a core biopsy spiritdeep rhodeeho

Posts.Content: Dec 11, 2013 11:52PM Ariom wrote: Undercat, I hope you don't mind me jumping in to answer your question about the bra you can wear a week out from a UMx. I am a "Uniboober" as we are sometimes called, almost a year out from my surgery 19th December last year. I have researched and acquired just about every kind of Foob, Boob and Prosthesis there is! LOL You may need to consider that you could still have a drain or two in place a week after surgery. I wore a Genie Bra with a soft fiber filled "foob" with my drain discretely threaded through the armhole of my top and into a soft cotton shoulder bag. Not the perfect way you'd want to meet the relatives, but better than having the drain pinned to the inside of your clothes. This is the worst case scenario! If you don't have a drain to worry about you can wear a Genie bra or a camisole with a soft "foob" pinned inside. I bought camisoles and bras I could step into, so I didn't overextend my arm. I wouldn't think you could handle anything more structured than those knitted bras or camisoles so soon after the surgery. It is possible that you may feel uncomfortable with anything tight or fitted against your skin. I am not meaning to scare you, but your skin can feel hypersensitive because of the nerve regeneration. I always say that I was really surprised that this wasn't a painful surgery, but a surgery of weird sensations! The last thing you want is to be feeling fidgety because you've chosen something too thick, or stiff to wear. I wish you all the very best for the 18th, and hope you have a great time with your relatives! Take care!

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2015 06:55AM Ariom wrote: Hi Bcky, I am a Uni too, no recon. You don't mention that you had recon, so I am assuming you didn't. The feeling of being punched in the sternum, that you are describing, was something I felt too, and a kind of sandpaper, sunburn which is caused by the regeneration of the nerves that have been cut. As time goes on, that will change to other zapping and zinging sensations. I guess you are also speaking of having a concave area, where the tissue was removed. Most of my discomfort came from the disturbance of the nodes under my arm. The iron bra and extreme tightness is what the girls with the TE's or immediate recon speak about. I did the exercises religiously 4x each day, even though I had cording too. It hurts to do it, but it will ensure you get your range of motion back quickly. I found doing the first lot of exercises for the day, under the hot shower worked for me. It is very early days for you and there is still lots of inflammation, deep bruising and swelling, you've been through a really brutal surgery! I gently massaged my chest with essential oils in a carrier oil base which helped a lot with that soreness in the sternum. I can't speak for the usefulness of the pain meds, I will do anything to avoid them and had none at all, for the entire process, because I registered discomfort and strange sensation, but not pain. Try to be kind to yourself, you're body is healing right now, but it will continue to change in both feeling and appearance. I am sure there will be others who will come along to share their expriences too. Take it easy!
Posts.Title: Pain after uni mx Bcky Bcky

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2015 09:04AM Ariom wrote: Awww, Bcky, I am so sorry you've had this crap to deal with. It isn't fair! I can't imagine what was holding up you LE garments, but at least they are on the way now. I know it's hard, but you have to try not to let the way others, "think" you should be doing, affect you. They have no clue what you have been through, or how your body is in extreme stress and healing mode, all at the same time. I couldn't understand what all the weird sensations were that I was feeling, so I actually watched a Mx surgery on the internet, purely for my own interest, certainly, this is not for everyone, but I have to tell you, it was brutal! I don't care what anyone says, I believe that even though we are knocked out, our body knows what is happening to it and that is why, like with all kinds of medical procedures, some people are affected more profoundly, than others. I was one who suffered extreme tiredness after my Umx. I don't do anesthesia well. I seriously, could drop off to sleep mid sentence in the early weeks, after surgery. That's very normal! If anyone gives you a hard time, just smile and say "We can discuss this again, when you've been through something similar!" Gentle hugs to you! Take care of you and let us know how you're doing!

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2013 12:21AM Ariom wrote: Hi 46andsingle, I don't mind at all, ask away! I will be 60 next birthday, so much older than you, and in a very different situation. I can't say what I'd have done if I was single and in my 40's, but I still think it would have been a struggle for me to reconstruct. My Mother had a Radical Mastectomy in '94, just four months after my Dad passed away. I was so used to seeing her scar, and hearing her humour about it that seeing myself like that wasn't as big an issue as it could be for some. When I got my Dx, one of the first things I said was that I wouldn't be reconstructing, so could I have the best scar possible. When I woke after surgery, my Surgeon was there to tell me he done "The straightest scar, he'd checked it with a spirit level!"LOL I was told, however, that the door wasn't closed, if I decided to do a reconstruction later it would be possible. I must admit I liked that, I don't like being told that I "can't do" something. My husband is a C5/6 Quadraplegic from a hang gliding accident 35 years ago. He has been a rock for me and has absolutely no issue with me being a "Uniboober". His reaction  to seeing me on day one was to say "Oh Wow! that will heal beautifully!" and "You don't need two boobs to be gorgeous!" The truth is he wouldn't have a problem if the other one had to go the way of the first, but I didn't feel the need to have a BMX when there wasn't a problem with the other breast. You've got so much to think about, it is so hard when huge decisions have to be made so quickly. I really feel for you! I am sure there are others here, closer to your age, who are single and have been faced with the same decision you're facing right now. I am sure they will come along and try to help you with their experiences. Please ask anything you wish, we are all willing to share our experiences. I wish you all the very best with whatever you choose for you, please stay around and let us know what you decide, and then how you are doing.

Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2013 03:43PM Ariom wrote: Hi Momine, Sorry this is proving to be so difficult. I have just received my Amoena Contact. I had a problem with the Amoena light that I bought. so returned it and got the Contact instead. Have you watched the video for the Contact on the Amoena website? The reason I went for this prosthesis, which I should have bought right from the start, is because it can be attached to the chest inside a normal bra. It can also have the sticky side covered and used inside a pocket Mx bra. The video on the website shows a woman, who has had a Umx and is very small, as you describe yourself. I can't use this prosthesis attached for a while yet because they say you have to wait till 6 months after surgery, but I have tried it on several times and really like it. I have a deep concave below my scar going under my arm, but this still sits well and atttaches into the dip. Inside a bra it falls just like the real one. I have been on the hunt for the "perfect" prosthesis, but have discovered that for me, there are several options that I need. I know it sounds very over the top to have the softees, the microbeads, the Contact, and the Basic Light Amoena, but to be able to match the other side in all circumstances, that is what it takes. It is really easy for me now, to dress exactly as I choose.  The reality is that I haven't spent a great deal of money on these items. Our Government reinburses $400.00 on single prosthesis, every two years. We're out of pocket for the difference, and when you consider most prosthesis here in Aus are approx $450.00, much more expensive than in the US, but I don't know about Greece where you are, it is a reasonable shortfall, but is recoverable from our private health insurance if we have it. I have insurance, so my Contact was paid in full. The others I have bought online, the everyday Basic light from ebay, and the microbeads from websites in the US. I discovered another interesting product last night called "BustFree"Mastectomy Prosthesis which I believe is a double up of two sizes of their standard BustFree Bra inserts. It was apparently invented here in Australia, I am not sure how well it would work for me, being Umx, but for you,it may be worth a look. At approx $40.00 for the pair, it is a mighty cheap option for you, and no weight whatsoever. If they work, they would be ideal for those who can't take the weight of a silicone prosthesis. Although I prefer the Mx bras, Amoena Mona, being my favourite, and a great cotton one that is Target's own brand is another great one, the beauty of these prosthesis is that they can be worn in a normal bra. In fact the non prosthesis advertising says that you don't even need  a bra, that these things can be held in place by a cami, vest, or a tight Tshirt.    I'd love to hear from anyone who has tried these, either for Umx or Bmx. Sorry to be so long winded, but just wanted to share what I have found.

Posts.Content: Mar 28, 2013 06:20AM Ariom wrote: Hi Momine, I am so sorry, but I snorted hot tea when I read this. Hot tea in the nose is not nice, but the picture you paint of the drooping silicone foobs was priceless. Please don't be offended, I don't mean to make light of it, but you just have a way with your words that got me laughing. I bought an Amoena Natura Light, they advertise this as a very natural looking foob that conforms when you lie down. It is supposed to look really natural, but the truth is it is really "perky", and a tad too hard in comparison to the real one. It has a very slight ski jump shape, but doesn't droop excessively, and is much more mooshy, and soft, more like an almost 60 year old breast feels. Sorry if that is TMI.   I have to ask, were they actually prosthesis that you bought? or enhancers that go on top of real breasts. I found myself in a site the other night that catered for cross dressers. They even have a recipe for making your own silicone foobs. Very interesting! I digress LOL Did you put them in a pocketed bra, or just in a normal bra? Were they ones that attached to your chest? If you are putting heavy silicone foobs in an Ahh bra, type bra, that may be your problem. They aren't made to go together. Can you give some more information? I'd love to help you work out what went wrong with these "foobs".

Posts.Content: Nov 22, 2013 10:03PM Ariom wrote: I had this sensation when I had my Mx in the super hot Summer, last year. I ordered a frozen Coke on a scorching hot day and thought I may pass out from the chest freeze! LOL I then found it happened, to a lesser extent, with really hot liquids too. This subject has been discussed here quite a lot. It seems to happen early on after the surgery, and generally starts to dissipate and finally disappears within the first year or so. I call this Mx surgery, the surgery of strange sensations. Another one that I named "The Claw" seems to be common too. It is the sensation of a large sharp claw holding the front of the chest and underarm. It usually hits when you've overdone it, manifesting at the end of the day. Between these sensations and the raspy sunburned feeling from the regenerating nerves, the numbness, and the phantom itching, it's all pretty weird. I am almost a year out from my Mx, and most of these strange feelings are gone now. I am still numb, but have gotten used to it. As time goes by, things just start to become "The New Normal".

Posts.Content: Dec 26, 2013 08:48PM Ariom wrote: Hi Blessings, I had another very weird procedure done in Singapore years ago. I had what they called a Micoplasma Infection. I have decided to have  the very end of my "Dog Ear" fixed, it is just a small protrusion of about 2cm which drives me nuts because it sometimes hangs over my bra and I have to tuck it back in. Yuck! I just hope that removing that doesn't start up any more nerve nonsense in that area.

Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2013 06:19PM Ariom wrote: Hi Tb, so nice to hear from you, and thank you for the lovely, but not necessary compliments! Colin is one out of the box, I have to say. It's weird, but watching someone with the kind of daily struggle that he has, but he never complains about, makes my perspective on my own things, a bit different to the way they were, before he entered my life. He has been an excellent leveler for me.  He never fails to amaze me with his positivity. He has been my rock. My surgeon explained to me that they don't want to draw everything too tight when they close because it can effect your range of motion, an that it will get better with time. It is also affected by weight loss and gain. My "Dog Ear" has improved incredibly over the past 12 months, but there is just a little section at the very end that troubles me. It isn't a vanity thing,  it really bugs me, as yours does, when it is being rubbed by the side of my bra. It is kind of numb, but has some nerve, electric zaps, going on too. My surgeon was very open to repairing it, when I last saw him in September, but I wasn't keen on having more surgery, well actually not the surgery, but the anesthetic, is what I want to avoid. I decided to see how much it would bother me during the Summer, when I would be wearing sleeveless tops etc. It's early in our Summer but I have decided that I just want the very end, which has a slightly pointed protrusion, to be removed. I am sure that this will be able to be done with a local anesthetic and a few stitches, or even glue. That will still leave me with a slight fold, but I am loathe to remove it all because I don't want to risk any range of movement. I see my surgeon again at the end of January, so I'll arrange it at that meeting, and I'll let you know what transpires.  I am so interested to hear about Blanch, we have large flocks of these Sulphur Crested Cockies, as we call them all around us. They are the noisy birds of the area, there squauking is like nothing else around here, but they are beautiful to see. They fill some of the big trees when I go walking. It is an amazing sight for a city girl! We also have the Black Cockies over on the Island too. Our main draw card here is the huge population of Pelicans. I can get up some mornings and there can be 60 or more right outside on the water. The main domestic bird that you see here is the Pink and Grey Galah. They are pretty loud too, but learn to speak and dance and do tricks. My ex had one at his Mother's house. She would go out to call the cat and the dog, who were Frank and Zappa, in for dinner, then for the rest of the evening Gus, the bird would be shouting Frank Zappa! I guess you had to be there! LOL They live to a very old age, and I have heard of these birds being passed down the family. Sorry to have hijacked this thread a bit, but I will let you know about the "Dog Ear"

Posts.Content: Nov 14, 2014 03:51AM Ariom wrote: Hi CeceliaVera, I had some cording too. I started to massage around my scar right after my Umx and continued it over the incision line once it was healed. I went to a massage therapist every 2 weeks, who did myofascial release. I did use aromatherapy oils in carrier oils, to massage my chest, but this was an analgesic blend that I have used for many years, for the pain of Rheumatoid arthritis and to help with the scarring I have, from several Rheumatoid surgeries. I swear by it and it does keep the skin really soft and supple. My concern was mostly about not getting good range of motion back in my shoulder, post surgery, because of the arthritis, but the massage and the stretching exercises prevented that and I had a fairly quick return, to full range of motion. The cording was tight, but it did resolve on its own, with the help of the massage. One of the cords did snap when I rolled over in bed one night! I also found I got great results from using silicone strips on my incision line. My surgeon had introduced me to them for my previous surgeries, to take the redness out and to flatten my scars. I bought a 22" Silicone FX strip, cut it in 2 and I had the 2 to use, for several months along my Umx scar and then I used one again, for the 7cm extension to my Umx scar, when I had my Dog Ear removed, over a year after the Umx surgery. These strips are used for burns and cosmetic surgeries. They may not work for everyone, but for me they were fantastic. I am almost 2 years out now and the scars are really fine and silver and my chest is supple, so for me, it was definitely worth all the effort and commitment. Good luck with it!

Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2014 06:49PM Ariom wrote: Hello Farley, I understand how you feel. There are a lot of very expensive forms on the market, but there are ways to get the best products, for minimal costs. I am assuming you don't have insurance that will offset the cost of real forms and bras? I have heard that in the US many of the insurance companies cover a lot of items. Quite different to where I am, I buy most of my Mx items from the US. I would advise you, to at least go to a fitter and be fitted for a proper Mx bra or 2 and a few different forms, You can then shop online, at sales and on Ebay for the items that suit you, at hugely reduced prices. It isn't unusual to be able to pick up both new bras and often forms for around $20.00 on Ebay. It also depends on the size that you are, as to what kind of mock ups you will be comfortable with. If you are a very small size, you can get away with the Ahh Bras and Camisoles with department store enhancers, or even by packing some soft wadding in behind the modesty pads that come in those items. Vintage Girl, one of our members has discovered some really nice bras that can be converted that way. If you are a larger size, then I would recommend you actually try a real form, there are weighted foam forms, as well as basic silicone forms. The Mx bras are cut completely differently to a regular bra. They have a different underarm, in case of discomfort after node removal and they have a different cut to the straps which prevents them from ever falling down your shoulders.  There isn't much I haven't tried since my Mx in 2012, but although they can be expensive, I have found properly designed Mx products, fitted properly, are worth at least, some investment.  Properly taken care of, these items last and last. Take a look at Erica's site breastfree.org, she has a wealth of information on forms and clothing. There is also a closing down sale at womenspersonalhealth.com right now with great reductions on lots of high end items, but you would need to be sure of sizing first. I wish you all the very best!

Posts.Content: Jul 18, 2014 12:00AM Ariom wrote: Hi MissSunshine, I am sorry you are experiencing this additional pain. I wonder if you are experiencing the nerve regeneration that comes after this surgery. It can be felt as zinging pain or some feel like sandpaper has rubbed their skin and the whole area becomes so sensitive that even clothing brushing against you, can set up  the discomfort. If you still have drains, it could well be those that are irritating something in your chest. I had the sandpaper feeling as well as cording which was uncomfortable. I found that light massage helped as did persisting with the PT exercises each day. I am pleased you are going to speak with your Doctor, for peace of mind. I wish you all the best and hope you can get relief soon.

Posts.Content: Jul 2, 2014 06:31AM - edited Jul 2, 2014 06:32AM by Ariom Hello Alfieval, so sorry to hear of your experience and your disappointment in your final surgical outcome. I had a "dog ear" which is the term used for these pouchy bits that are left after Mx surgery. My surgeon explained it to me as flesh that used to be pulled forward by the weight of the breast and really just presents where they finish the incision. I hated mine and the fact that it had what felt like a buzzing bunch of cut nerves inside it, made it something I wanted rid of. I waited just over 12 months before having mine excised and it was the best thing I ever did. I waited, because I really wanted to see how much it would change over time  and if I became more used to it. When I realized that I was  always going to be feeling for it, because it would come over the side of my bra, and I was constantly annoyed by it, it wasn't a hard decision. There is a before and after set of pictures on Breastfree.org. Take a look and see if this is the same thing you have. You'll see that the after picture shows nothing but a fine scar and taught flat skin. I wish you all the best and feel free to PM me, or ask anything here, if I can help with any queries about this surgery.

Posts.Content: Jan 3, 2014 09:26PM Ariom wrote: Just wanted to jump in here I had a Mx last Dec 2012.  I am obviously not sure, but it sounds like you may have the same thing I had. I had a seroma and a hematoma and a small infection. I also discovered a weird ropey, lumpy thing coming from where my nipple had been. It snaked down my abdomen and branched off like a tree. There was another one that was under my rib cage. It is called Mondors Disease, and although not hugely common it happens after any kind of trauma to the breast and is very much like a Varicose vein. This isn't the same as a DVT which is a blood clot and can be very dangerous. They have other names for this too Phlebitis, Thrombosis. These cords are related to the lymph cording that many women get under their arm after surgery. Mine was a burning, pulling, discomfort, especially when I did the PT stretching exercises. In fact one of mine did pop when I turned over in bed one night. Mondors Cording not dangerous and is self limiting, which means it actually just goes away on its  own. Massage and heat can help to break it up. I massaged it myself and used heat packs, I also had it massaged by a therapist, who also massaged my chest to help avoid adhesions. Mine was gone by the 3 month mark after surgery.   It is definitely something that needs to be checked out. I was very surprised by the lack of information about it, but it seems to be more common in women who have breast augmentation.  I wish you all the very best, and hope that this turns out to be something that resolves quickly!

Posts.Content: Jul 17, 2014 03:46PM Ariom wrote: Alfieval, I am so pleased to hear your great news! I am sorry though that you're still experiencing the pain and I am so sorry to hear of your loss. I don't know how I would have fared without my Husband for support. Do you massage the chest and underarm at all? I get great relief from massage with oils and Essential Oils that act as analgesics. If you can see a PT, you may find you can get great relief from just a couple of visits. They can work wonders for this post surgery stiffness and cording. I must say, I was told only to exercise where it felt comfortable, not to push it too soon and not to overdo if I felt any pain. I had cording, even had one of them snap when I rolled over in bed one night. I had PT massage for that too and it worked very well for me. Don't beat yourself up over the SNB. As it turned out, I didn't need mine either, but for me, I would do the SNB again in a heartbeat, to be sure that I didn't have to have an Axillary Clearance if any invasion had been found, in my final pathology. It happens so much, even when totally unexpected. I know it can feel like a damned if you do and damned if you don't situation. I just look at it as the best of a gamble, I had to take. My Mother had an Axillary Clearance in the days before SNB, it turned out she had no invasion, but she had problems with LE for the rest of her life, I often wonder how different her remaining years would have been had she had been able to have a SNB and not that full clearance. I wish you well Alfieval, I would like to know how you get on. As difficult as it is, try to take it a little easier on yourself, you have been though an awful lot and just need some time to heal and feel better.

Posts.Content: Jul 12, 2014 03:39PM - edited Jul 12, 2014 03:41PM by Ariom Hi FranfromFL, I understand your fears, but at 11 days post surgery it is such a recent thing, that there will be many changes in the coming months. I would urge you not to get too involved in the post surgery pain syndrome, yet. There will be much healing and still a lot of nerve regeneration which will go on for some time. If you have got a fluid build up from early removal of your drain, you may well have a seroma. Don't worry too much about that either, it is very common. I had one that looked like the wave of a waterbed across my chest, which I had drained once and then left to reabsorb by my body. It took some time, but resolved by itself.  The other thing that I didn't mention in the previous post was exercises and massage. I know that PT exercises aren't pushed in the US like they are here, in Australia, but I did the stretching exercises given to me by my PT before I left the Hospital, 4 x a day religiously, to prevent adhesions. I also massaged my chest a couple of times every day, after the steri strips and dressing were removed, with essential oils in a carrier oil, to help with the soreness and to keep my skin supple. I don't know if you had a SNB, but that was the most uncomfortable part for me, with numbness and soreness down the inside of my arm. Again, I used massage every day to get that back, to feeling somewhat "normal". I also go to a massage therapist regularly and she has done Myofascial  release massage on my chest too. I am not suggesting that you should do this, but I was so surprised at the strange sensations that I was experiencing, after my surgery, that I watched a Mx surgery on the internet. It is a truly brutal surgery, so although I have to say, pain wasn't the issue for me, I can understand how disrupted everything is after this surgery. The nerve regeneration, which goes on for some time is likely what you're experiencing, but for most, it becomes tolerable and then dissipates over time. I hope your pain subsides soon, as I said before, your Doctors are the best ones to advise you, but I hope some of this info may assist you too!

Posts.Title: So Scared purple_shmoo purple_shmoo

Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2014 11:10PM Ariom wrote: Hi FranfromFl, I had a UMx about 18mths ago. I guess it is important to say that I don't think there is a "Normal" for surgery as such. We are all different, have different pain tolerance and even the same type of surgery affects some of us differently. I didn't experience pain at all, and didn't take any pain medication at all, but I did have lots of strange sensation which ranged from a burning, sandpaper or severe sunburn sensation and zingers from regenerating nerves and numbness and pins and needles from the SNB. Those who have reconstruction and tissue expanders speak of considerable pain and tightness. You don't mention if you reconstructed. As WarriorWoman, said, if you are concerned and experiencing pain that feels like it is more than it should be, your Surgeon would be the best person to talk to. If it were me, I would take over the counter pain medication 4 or 6 hourly for a couple of days to see if that makes a difference to the way it feels. I'd make sure there wasn't any redness or that I wasn't running a temperature and if still not feeling right, I'd call and speak to the surgeon.  I wish you all the best for a speedy recovery! It is still very early days for you, less than 2 weeks, so take it easy, you still have a lot of healing to do.
Posts.Title: Post Surgical Pain FranfromFL Ariom

Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2014 04:18PM Ariom wrote: Oh Val, I am so sorry to hear you're feeling low. It isn't uncommon to ave a lot of stuff bubble to the surface after such a stressful time. I kind of went the other way and kept running on adrenaline for a while. I have never been one to cry, but I found I could be set off by a sad TV commercial, even now, but I didn't feel sad, if that makes any sense. I was the queen of the incision massage! LOL I still do it every day. It took a while for the swelling to go down and I had the Seroma too, that lasted months. I also had the pouchy thing, which is called a Dog Ear, I had that removed more than a year later. It is a long process Val, but it does get better. I don't know how I would have fared in the early days after the surgery, if I was on my own. Do you have anyone close, to spend time with when you feel a bit teary? We have been through a big, life changing event, with much fear and brutal surgery, anesthesia that takes a long time to completely leave us, so don't expect to feel 100% early on. I was pretty happy with my scar, once it had healed and the swelling dissipated, and finally when the dog ear was gone. I have one section of the scar where it opened up and I had an infection which has ruined the nice fine line I had hoped for, but all in all, I can ignore that and just deal with it as it is. It isn't unusual to have a revision to get the chest flat, I have read of women having revisions after it has all settled down. It is still very early days , it was June wasn't it, for you? Try to take it one step at a time. I am coming up for 20 months, which I can't believe, but I had to realize it was a process and let it run its course. You will be fine, you've been through a lot. Keep in touch, I look forward to hearing from you!

Posts.Content: Oct 25, 2014 01:37AM Ariom wrote: I would really love to find out what the difference is, in the different Hospitals and different countries. I have been involved in every one of these threads, on this subject, since I started coming here almost 2 years ago. My Surgeon was trained and worked in South Africa where he started breast clinics all over he country, he did the same in England and then came to the region where I live in Australia. He has been doing  breast and Mx surgeries for many years and was really surprised that I was stressed and worried about having this SNB done. I told him about the stories I had heard, about this horrific pain and he told me he had never had a patient tell him, they'd had a bad experience having it done. What the!!!!, How can that be! I just don't get it! I certainly don't doubt the word of anyone who has had this test and felt extreme pain. I guess there must be some relevance to pain threshold, I have Rheumatoid Arthritis, so  I am used to extreme pain, but I really felt nothing, when I had my SNB. I went into it tense and afraid, which I would have thought, would just exacerbate pain. I had 4 shots, all in the areola, just like the others, who had such a bad experience. I remember reading somewhere that there are solutions which have different PH levels, which may be something to consider. My tech was very good, he did talk me through the whole procedure, he had a lovely personality and did everything to make me feel comfortable and relaxed. One thing, I must say though, I don't agree with some of the really over the top, extreme descriptions, of this procedure, which I have seen in the past, on these boards. These do nothing, but strike fear into the hearts of newbies who may be facing the procedure and have come here for support.  I really do wish this procedure could be painless for everyone.

I would never minimize the fact, some do have a painful experience, but it is the really over the top descriptions, that I object to. I really wasn't terribly afraid of the Mx, but the accounts and descriptions, by some people I spoke to and read posts by, about the unbearable, extreme, intractable pain of this procedure, really rattled me. I don't believe in sugar coating it, this procedure is not the same for everyone, but striking such terrible fear into the hearts of women who are already afraid and about to have this procedure done, along with other life changing surgery, is just plain wrong and unnecessary. The long weeks I spent freaking out about it, after being assured, it would be the worst experience of my life, is time I will never get back.

Posts.Content: Apr 5, 2013 05:42AM Ariom wrote: Hi Sam, I am sorry, but I don't have any answers for you either, but I wanted to say Hi, and let you know you aren't alone. You have a history with this breast isssue, and you are doing everything right. Having the Biopsy is the right thing to do, and the only way to find out what is going on. Three weeks is a long time to wait for results, but we all understand how awful the waiting is, we've all done it. Try to keep yourself busy, and stay away from Google, Come here when you need to, we all know what you're going through. The vast majority of these breast issues turn out to be benign, so try not to go there in your mind. Easier said than done, I know. When it comes to your pain in the hip and the night sweats, there is nothing to say that any of this is related. I personally had night sweats, on and off from when I was 38 and started to go through early menopause, it was all over by the time I was 43. I have arthritis too, and it is always at its worst at night, so it is quite possible you could have similar to me. None of this was in any way related, and I will be 60 next birthday, my diagnosis was in November last year, a very long time after these episodes. I am not suggesting that you're going through early menopause or that you have arthritis, just that there are so many things that it "could" be. Try to be kind to yourself and do things you enjoy while you are waiting. Come here, and let us know how you are doing! ((((((((hugs))))))))

Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2014 06:13PM Ariom wrote: Hello Mella, I am sorry I didn't see this post earlier! Another member sent me a message to say you were needing some Foob advice! That's what is so great about this site, everyone is always looking out for each other!  Congratulations! One week out and your are "Foob"  hunting. I was just the same and so were many others here.In fact, I turned up at the lingerie shop in the next big town from the small one I live in one week after my surgery. The ladies were very kind, asked me if I was having a Mx, but when I said I'd had it a week earlier they just shooed me away and said they couldn't fit me for at least 6 weeks. I was back 6 weeks to the day for my fitting and really haven't looked back. I am the same size as you, had a UMX 15 months ago and have acquired such a wardrobe of Boobs Foobs and Prosthesis that one of our members here named their home in my dressing room "The FoobMoire!" I would suggest you take a look at the website breastfree.org, it is run by one of our members Erica and she has put together an extensive range of options for Prosthesis. Their is a lot of great information on that site. I discovered very early on, that my low neck tops, even T shirts had to go, and I have replaced everything with higher necklines so that when I bend forward, the gap is not visible. When you get into a silicone Prosthesis that gap can be more visible as the heavy prosthesis falls forward. I have also discovered that I like to wear sports crop tops that can take a light weight foam foob. They are not as structured as a real Mx bra and feel very light, firm against the chest, which I like and they prevent "fall forward"! Obviously they can't be worn all the time, but they are a great alternative for casual wear. I find I am wearing casual yoga pants, crop bra, with an Active Wear jacket zipped up to show the crop a little as my casual or relaxing wear. I would definitely suggest that you get properly fitted for your silicone prosthesis and Mx bras. I did that and then started to find things after I knew what worked for me. I have bought many prosthesis and bras, all new, on Ebay, with great success. Their are a multitude of styles out there, many of them are nice to look at too. You don't have to sacrifice nice lingerie, just because you need a Mx bra. Remember you need to wait at least 6 weeks! Also, take a look at the Mx camisoles, there are quite a few manufacturers who make them, my fave is the Valletta by Amoena. They have a bra inside, more structured than say a Genie bra, but less structured than a full Mx bra. They work very well alone, under a shirt, cardigan or jacket. I have them in about 4 colors, once you get the straps fitted right, it will sit flat against your chest and it feels great. I had the same problem that you do, in the very early days. The balancing act with a heavy " C/D" cup on one side can be a bit of an issue. I just put up with the riding up of the fiber filled foob, till I got fitted. I did buy Genie Bras from a department store, you know the knitted type with no wires or hooks, and I found a Target Post Surgery stretch cotton bra that had the hooks in the front because I had a bit of an issue with cording, so stretching to get the other ones over my head was a bit of a challenge. I also bought some micro bead Foobs from a lovely lady named Mary at mastectomysolutions.com she has the pattern for making them if you are a sewer, or she will make them for you for a very small charge. Mary's website is great too, she has lots of very good info there, in fact it was Mary who taught me to hand wash my Mx bras and use a salad spinner to get the water out before hanging out to dry. Great advice for caring for expensive bras. Although I have several silicone Prosthesis, even one called the "Contact" which has a sticky surface so it adheres to the skin of your chest and can be worn with a normal bra, without pockets. I do tend to wear my Tru Life weighted foam form a lot these days, but it is all just a matter of personal choice. The one great thing I can tell you Mella, is that it doesn't take long, till you just put the bra and form on and that's the last time you think about it, till you remove it at night.   Please feel free to message me if there is anything else I can help you with. I am sure there will be others along to offer their ideas and tips too. I know it feels a bit overwhelming at first, bu it gets better and as we become more used to the "New Normal" things fit into place. I even go half flat sometimes, a shape wear firm tank rails in that "D" puppy and no one ever seems to notice. Take care Mella...have fun shopping for things that make you feel good! M x
Posts.Title: C&D cup UMXs: Please share foob, bra & clothing links & tips MellaBella Ariom

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2014 10:25PM Ariom wrote: You're welcome! I am not sure if you are searching for front closers, they do have a tendency to be a bit more structured to look at, but if you are just searching for Mx bras with pockets, take a look at the Amoena "Mona" bra, it has become one of my favorites and I know a lot of others here, have bought  this one too. It is a little structured with a stay in the side of it, but it is a very comfortable and doesn't feel like armor!  The trick is to try on lots of different styles in stores and if you find some you really like, you can search them out on the internet. For me, it is worth my while to do it that way because everything Mx related in Aus is just so expensive. Although I would prefer to keep my money in my region by frequenting local businesses I just can't justify the huge disparity in price. For instance the Mona bra is $88.00 here but I can find them for 2 for $70.00US, even with freight, it is just too much of a difference. It is the same with Forms, $90.00 for my favorite weighted foam Tru Life in Aus and 2 for $72.00US in the States. I just ordered 2 more at that price to put away till the demise of the one I am wearing now . There are some very reasonable deals at different Mastectomy suppliers in the US, but even there you can find some pretty big price differences.

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2014 05:51PM - edited Apr 16, 2014 05:53PM by Ariom Hello Mella, the bra in the link you posted is almost identical the the Target brand bra I mentioned. The Target bra is a good cotton, with stretch and at $20.00 here in Australia it is a much better price than that one. I don't know if it is available in the US. Here in Aus, I just searched "Post Surgery" on the Target website and there were several that appeared. I have tried them all, but this one was my favorite. Also, Amoena has a great range of all different types of Mx bras, try their website if you like the type featured in the link look for their cotton stretch, or there is a lace front hook style for leisure wear that you may like. Take a look at the Valletta Camisole with built in bra and pockets, it is very comfortable and handles a full weight silicone Prosthesis, or a light weight  really well. I wore one of these to my first BC meeting after my surgery and I was asked if my surgery had been delayed. None of the girls had ever seen one of these camis before and they couldn't believe how good it looked. I have also bought shape wear tanks that have pockets for those modesty pad things. I can get a weighted foam foob into those with a snip of the fabric, the firmness of the body of the tank keeps everything, including the foob in place. They work well under a shirt or waterfall cardigan.  The one thing I should mention, is that Mx bras are cut quite differently to normal bras. The cups have more coverage to be able to hide the Form and any concave parts of your chest and the best design element is the straps are cut toward the inner chest so you never have to worry about the straps falling down and the Form being exposed. Women who are smaller sizes seem to be able to get away with normal bras or having their old bras modified with a pocket, but my attempts to modify and keep some of my much loved lingerie failed, because the shapes are off now. I know I can sound like a broken  record about this, so forgive me if you've heard it before, but I will never wear an under wire bra again because a member here posted that she was stabbed by a wayward wire, in and area where she was still numb and she sustained a very bad infection from that. Once you begin to research what is available and find what suits your individual needs, you'll be surprised by how much is actually out there. Edited to add...I believe Nordstroms have a service where they will put pockets into bras bought from them.

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2015 04:33AM Ariom wrote: Hello GingerChi! and dianeaslm, So glad you have found us, there are many women here who have had the same surgery and will come to share their experiences with you. I am a Uni, no reconstruction, so I have a remaining breast, but I can identify with the sensations you are experiencing. When people asked me about how this surgery felt, was it really painful? I always said, for me, not painful, in the traditional sense, but it is a surgery of very weird sensations. As dianeslm said, there is so much healing going on, there is a lot of nerve regeneration as nerves that were cut try to reattach, across the abyss. There are the drains, which are necessary, but uncomfortable and the relief when they are removed is something we all agree on. Then there is the possibility of a Seroma, which is a buildup of fluid, it may or may not be taken up by the body, or your Surgeon can extract it by syringe. The other very uncomfortable aspect of this surgery is the area under your arm where the Lymph Nodes have been disturbed by either a SNB or having more of the nodes removed. This is a very brutal surgery, many refer to it, as an amputation. I actually watched a Mx surgery on You Tube after my own Umx, not before, I wasn't that brave!LOL I wanted to see what was done that could manifest all these weird sensations. I now know and understand it better. There will be more sensations that you'll discover as time goes on, drinking cold water gives a Waterfall sensation inside your chest, don't panic, it goes away, as does the feeling that I named "The Claw" that feels much like sharp claw is holding your chest and underarm, this one really only comes at night and after a day when you have felt really good and have overdone it! We all do that! There is a feeling, much like raspy sunburn, which is nerve related too. The main thing for me was the abject tiredness, I could fall asleep mid sentence, in the first few weeks. I was religious with my PT exercises, from the day I left Hospital and I massaged my chest as soon as the incision was healed and the steri strips were gone. I drank gallons of water to flush the meds and anesthetic out of my system. I know it feels pretty awful right now, but it does get better and there are so many women here who can relate to the exact same things you're experiencing. Stick around and ask anything. I wish you both the very best for a speedy, uneventful recovery.

I went into my day of surgery with those descriptions vivid in my mind and terrified. I couldn't have given a crap about the Mx, I was just consumed with fear, irrational fear, of that SNB tracer. Posts.Content: Oct 23, 2014 05:58AM Ariom wrote: Just thought I would mention that this is an old thread that hasn't had any posts for the past year. It may start up again with your posts. Hi Abbey and Wendy and welcome to BCO. Sorry you have to be here.  You will find there will be lots of women who will help with support and will share their experiences.   As you can see, there are very different opinions and experiences with the SNB. It has been debated many times on these boards. No one really knows why it affects some people so badly and others not at all. When I spoke to my surgeon about the procedure, he was genuinely surprised that I was really concerned about it. He said he'd been doing this kind of surgery for many years and had never had any of his patients say it was a very painful procedure.  I went into mine on the morning of my UMx surgery, full of fear and trepidation because I had heard so many horror stories about how bad it was going to be. My Surgeon had given the OK, for me to have a numbing injection if I wanted it, but when I arrived early in the morning at the imaging department, the tech wasn't authorized to give lidocaine for this procedure. He rang my Surgeon at home and my Surgeon offered to drive down to administer the shot himself. There was no way I would allow him to come in early on a day when he'd be spending long hours in surgery, just for that. I am actually glad it happened that way. The tech talked me through the procedure. I had 4 shots into the areola and when I asked him when it was going to be painful, he said it was all over. I felt nothing, not even the needle, in that sensitive area, much less the tracer. It took several goes, for the tracer to actually get to the Sentinel Node. I had to massage for 20 minutes and then have another scan, on the 3rd attempt and the tech woo-hooed and came out with the film, showing the SN. He high fived me and took me up to surgery.   I have never experienced relief like that before, I felt like I was bulletproof and I breezed through the Umx, the blue dye was administered after I was anesthetized and I was out and home the following morning. Just like everything else, this a very personal experience. I just wish it could be painless for everyone.

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2014 08:07PM Ariom wrote: I am a bit confused about how they could do the whole procedure under GA. I had the tracer injected early in the morning of my Mx. Posts.Content: Jul 14, 2014 03:13PM - edited Jul 14, 2014 03:18PM by Ariom Hi Alfieval, I am so sorry to hear this has happened to you. It may well be just a minor setback, where you have overdone it. Many of us have setbacks during recovery and seromas are extremely common. I had one to that I had drained and there were times I had to pull right back and take it easy, because my body decided I was doing too much. It probably isn't the exercises, but whatever else you are up to in your daily life that is giving you the discomfort. I know I had strict instructions not to lift anything over 10lbs for the first month, well my dog weighs twice that! It was tough to keep to all the rules and I definitely overstepped on more than one occasion, and paid for it with pain and the sensation I named "The Claw". I am 19 months out and I can still invoke that feeling, like there is a sharp claw holding my underarm and chest if I really do a lot of heavy work. I know what it is now and will pull back if it happens. Try not to give yourself a hard time about this, it is a process and it can feel like we are going backwards, but being kind to yourself, it will get better. I know we all just want to get back to where we were before, but for me at least, there are sensations that have just become the New Normal and they don't really bother me, this far down the road. If it were me, I'd see the Doctor, just to put my mind at rest and to see if the seroma needs to be drained. I think I mentioned in an earlier post that the SNB area was and is the most uncomfortable part for me, even now, it is numb and can get irritated if clothing rubs against it.   I hope things improve quickly for you, let us know how you get on. Edited to say... 4 weeks is such early days Alfieval. I remember at 4 weeks, I was still falling asleep mid sentence, so you've done very well! Take it easy!

Posts.Content: Aug 31, 2014 01:47AM Ariom wrote: Hi Val, I hope you've had some rest and feel ready to go again. I have still had painters here this week and they will be back this week to finish. I have had to clear the junk I put in the guest room while the painters were in the house working and get the room ready for them. I have decided not to try again to keep in touch with the wife. I reached out, sent gifts, called several times, even called on the 1st anniversary to see how they were doing, but she never reciprocated. Just not meant to be. If you find the silicone prosthesis is too heavy for you, ask to try the lighter weight silicone which is available. I have found that many women here have gone for a fitting, only to be given something that the fitter thinks is right, when a lot more forms should have been tried, as other options. I know, I wasn't sure what I was looking for, at the beginning. I have actually moved on to mostly wearing a weighted foam leisure form. They are very cheap by comparison to the silicone, 2 for $72.00 or $40.00 each at MetroMedical.  I am not suggesting you should go for one of those over a silicone, if you're only allowed 1 through insurance. I much prefer wearing that, but still have my silicone forms for different bras etc.  I have a friend, whose DD is also looking at sperm bank baby, it is interesting isn't it! I am glad to see you're getting more movement from the exercises, that will make you feel better overall. I was tired beyond words after my surgery, it took a long time to get my energy back, even now I will have a nap occasionally in the afternoon. I go for my Yearly Mammo and U/S tomorrow, feels better than the last time, but I am still a little nervous. I don't think it will ever be easy. Take it easy, let me know how you appointment goes. Posts.Content: Mar 22, 2013 10:18PM Ariom wrote: Hi Virginia, Just try to slow down for a moment. We all know how scarey the unknown is. I am so glad you found us. This is a great place to be, while you wait for answers. We'll be here if you need us. Please don't google. If you have questions, ask them here. There is a lot of outdated information on Google that won't be relevant to you, and it will just scare you more. So far you have found a lump, but until you go to the Doctor and have it checked out you can't speculate on what it is. There are many, many things, other than cancer that this could be. Whenever there is a new person here, we always explain to them that even if you have to have this biosied, you have an 80%+ chance of this thing being Benign, not associated with cancer at all. It may not even get to that. One of our very wise contributors says "don't go there till you have to!" I know it is hard, but this stress wiill do you no good, and it won't change the outcome. Try to take it one step at a time. Make an appointment to have it looked at, and go from there. We are here for any questions you may have. Sometimes, lumps hurt, and the skin can be red, often from us constantly feeling for the lump. Pain killers are fine, if you need them, and stress can cause hot flashes too. Like I said earlier, there are many other things that this could be. I am so sorry that you're feeling so bad, it won't be long and you'll have answers. Let us know how you get on! ((((((((((((Hugs))))))))))))

Posts.Content: May 8, 2014 05:19AM Ariom wrote: Hi Nenny, as you can see by the posts, there are many options available. Two weeks out is very early days and it is normal to still feel sore, there is a lot of nerve regeneration and internal healing going on. I think most here will tell you that the node removal side is the most uncomfortable part of this surgery. I had a Umx, no recon at Christmas 2012 and I have researched and found lots of foobs and Prosthesis, Camis, Sports Crop Tops,Tanks and Shape wear. Genie bras work very well with soft forms in the early months before being fitted for Mx bras and Prosthesis, if that's what you decide to do. Swimwear by Amoena and Lands End have suits that are higher at the front. I also have a Speedo racing swim suit,  for water aerobics, going half flat was not something I thought I would do, but it isn't a problem to me now. It depends on whether you have decided to go flat all the time, or if you choose to wear forms of some sort, that will define what kind of suit you buy. (pockets or no pockets). I also had some tissue left at the end of my incision line, which is often called a "Dog Ear". I found it annoying, because it would sneak out over the side of my bra and it also had a lot of nerve discomfort too. Although I didn't think I would ever want to have any more surgery, I decided about a year down the track, which was a couple of months ago, to have it removed. For me, it was the best thing ever. It is smooth and flat and I no longer have the feeling of live nerves zinging away in it. There are some pictures on Breastfree, the website  badger mentioned. It has lots of information. which I also found invaluable, when I was researching what was available. when I was new to this. There are so many options, I have bought everything from foobs, to bras, to swimwear, on Ebay, so I am not sure which item that you're referring to. Let us know if we can help any further.
Posts.Title: Bi Lateral Mastectomy 2 weeks ago Nenny02 Ariom

Posts.Content: Aug 16, 2013 07:09PM - edited Aug 16, 2013 07:23PM by Ariom Hi cetictrek, Big hugs to you, I am so sorry to hear of your loss, and your dx. I am a "Uniboober!" about 8 months now. I still have a C/D "rogue puppy" on the other side, but I have put together a great array of Foobs and Prosthesis. There are so many different types available. When I first had my surgery I had a softee that came with a knit bra. I just pinned it inside a cami top. I was at the fitter a week after surgery for my fitting for the prosthesis! When they discovered I was only one week out from surgery they shooed me away, and wouldn't fit me till I was 6 weeks post op. If you have a Target nearby, just a man style shirt, cotton with some elastane is all you need. They work with capris or jeans, or a skirt. They make them in every size. A few different scarves take the eye away from the chest. I bought one black and one white, and wore them with tank tops or camis underneath, and a scarf. If it is cool at night, or you're going out, a pashmina draped around the shoulders in a contrast color or pattern can dress this plain shirt up. I also wore jewellry high on my chest with a couple of buttons undone. The sleeves rolled up and bangles also take the eye away from the centre of the body. I hope this has been of some help....Take care!

Posts.Content: May 9, 2014 06:16AM Ariom wrote: I am also a Uni with a size "D" on the other side. I have many different foobs and Prosthesis, but I too, often go without, and don't feel any lop sided issues. The fitter that I went to, for my first bra and Prosthesis fitting, tried to tell me that I had to wear a weighted prosthesis all the time, but I like to wear a firm fitted shape wear tank or a firm Active wear bra or crop top with a zip jacket and yoga pants. I like to be really comfortable during my relaxation time and found this kind of casual wear took the pressure off when I was tender, and healing from the initial surgery and then when I had extra revision surgery. No one seems to notice when I go flat on that side One of my favorite forms is the weighted foam form by Tru Life, which doesn't weigh as much as the Silicone forms and feels really natural. I should mention too, that not all forms will be the same number size, they can vary quite considerably, so always check the size chart for the specific brand you are interested in, if you're purchasing without a fitter.  It is all just trial and error, you'll find what feels comfortable and suits you.

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2015 08:35PM - edited Jan 28, 2015 08:35PM by Ariom Hi Glennie and TB! My Uni sisters! Hello mtrebotske, I am another Uni, who doesn't have any regrets, about my decision. I knew from the very beginning that recon would never, be something I could do. I don't have anything against anyone else doing it and I love it when I hear a good recon result story, but as Glennie said, having that foreign thing inside me, was not something I could deal with, either! I also couldn't in good conscience, remove my healthy breast, but that is just me.I had a Mother who was a Uni, so I was fortunate, to have her experience to draw on and for me, having a functioning, healthy breast, is a good thing! I am very similar to TB, in that, I have a very understanding husband who made certain I would never have any self esteem issues, right from the get go. I must admit to feeling a tad apprehensive, but when he saw my scar, for the first time, the morning after my surgery, he said "Wow! that will heal really well, you don't need 2 boobs to be gorgeous!" That set the scene for me and I haven't looked back. If he feels like that, I couldn't care less, what anyone else thinks! We also have a lot of lighthearted banter, with my adult daughter joining in, too. I feel much like TB, I haven't any ongoing issues My Husband has no issue whatsoever with the way my chest looks or feels, in fact we really like how I can snuggle in closer to him in bed and I can feel his heart, through my flat side. I have a huge collection of foobs, boobs and prosthesis, lingerie with pockets and clothing that can hold my forms too. One of our members here, actually named the place I keep everything "The FoobMoire" LOL We all have funny stories about foobs, but like the others, I just don't think about it any more. Once I decide what I am wearing each day, that's it, till I take that outfit and foob off, at night. I occasionally go half flat and even though I am a "D" on the remaining side, I can wear a firm, shape wear tank top and no one notices. I wish you all the very best, with your decision and hope hearing from the 3 of us, who have very similar stories, may help you in some small way. There will be others along, who will share their experiences too!

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2014 05:20PM Ariom wrote: Great advice, and information from AZ. I totally agree that it is a huge and very personal decision, and there are as many reasons for the decisions as there are women here on this Forum! AZ has given you insight into the BMX she chose. I am wading in with the UMX or single Mx, and SNB that I chose. I was Dx with stage 0, grade 3, I was given the option of a lumpectomy and Radiation or a Umx. I didn't want to do the radiation if there was any way to avoid it, so I chose to have the single Mx and took the chance that there wouldn't be any little surprises that would indicate I would need Radiation after that surgery. I was very fortunate that I had no invasion, and my margins were clear. I never really considered doing a BMX, my Mother had a UMX back in the 90's and I believe her way of dealing with it and my exposure to her journey made it an easier choice, for me. I also chose not to reconstruct and haven't looked back, or regretted either of my decisions. I am 15 months out from surgery, and although I was a bit nervous at my first follow up appointment and first Mammogram, I am feeling more confident now and don't have the fear I had initially, about a possible problem in my remaining side.   Living with one breast is a bit of a challenge at the start, but once you realize what suits you and find what is comfortable for you, then when you find the right bras and Prosthesis, it all gets much easier. I wish you all the very best with your decision. You will know what feels right for you!
Posts.Title: surgery kgruenhagen Tdickinson

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2013 09:50PM Ariom wrote: You're welcome Sunflowers! Thank you for posting that link! I was introduced to these exercises by a friend who was an ex ballet dancer. He worked for an airline at the same time I did. He was on board a stationary aircraft, and leaned against the safety barrier across the open door. The barrier failed and he fell out onto the concrete tarmac, shattering his shoulder and his foot. It took many operations to repair his injuries, and he was laid up for a long time. Someone told him about the Rites, so he tried them out very slowly, till he could add to them and finally accomplish the 21reps after almost a year. He still does 21 reps a day, years after his accident. When my friend heard of my Dx, he got in touch with me and hassled me till I promised to try these Rites. I am so grateful I listened. He still emails me all the time to make sure I am not being tardy! He is totally devoted to the Rites, and swears it was the reason he was able to recuperate so well and is doing better, generally, than before his accident. It is very important to start at 3 reps and stay there as long as you need to. Only increase by one or two reps a week. It doesn't matter if you can't manage the 21 reps, you wouldn't believe the improvement after even a short time at 3 reps. Take care, and enjoy!

Posts.Content: Mar 22, 2015 12:03AM Ariom wrote: Hello bassetlover! another Uni here and Glennie is right, I do have a FoobMoire!LOL I was another who had that gut feeling that recon was not for me and over 2 years down the track, I have never regretted that decision. Please make the decision based on what you want, not what someone else thinks you should do. If you decide that you don't want recon, you must make sure your Surgeon is on the same page, you need to make your wishes very clear. I told my Surgeon I wanted a very straight scar and flat chest. There isn't any rush, I was assured that I could always reconstruct later if I changed my mind. I can't see it ever being something, I'd want to do, but it is good to have the option.You'll be surprised how many of us there are, both Uni's and BMX. The bras, clothing and forms available now, are pretty impressive. Take your time, try not to feel pressured. You can ask anything here, we are all happy to share our experiences.

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2014 12:43AM Ariom wrote: Hello ThinkingPositive, Everything you've reported here sounds very normal to me. I had the swelling too and I also had a Seroma, which was drained once, but it filled again and my Surgeon decided to let it resolve itself. It is a nerve wracking time after the surgery, waiting for the final pathology. It is very unlikely that they could tell anything during the surgery, it needs to be a Pathology report done on the tissue, to be sure of anything. My final Pathology took a long time to come back because my surgery was right before Christmas and the labs were closed over the Christmas break. Try not to be worrying too much about the final Pathology, just try to relax and be kind to yourself, while you heal from this surgery. I know how easy it is to overdo it, when you think you're feeling ok, but your body will let you know that it is time to slow down again. I found, I could almost drop off to sleep mid sentence in the beginning! I wish you all the very best! Write down any questions you have for your appointment, I always found if I didn't write it down, I'd be kicking myself on the way home, because I forgot to ask something. Take care and let us know how you get on.

Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2014 02:47AM Ariom wrote: Hello Lexigirl, so sorry you have to be here, but this is a much better place to be, than consulting Dr Google! We all understand just what you're going through. There is a lot of very relevant info here on this site that is much more reliable than a lot that is out there, on the internet.  I had a Stereotactic Vacuum Assisted Core biopsy and recently had an U/S guided core biopsy. For me, apart from a tiny sting for a second, when they put in the numbing agent they were both completely painless. There is a clicking sound as the cores are taken by the gun. The radiographers both talked me through what they were doing and in my first one the Radiographer explained it all as they took each core and it was displayed on a large screen. Holding the position was a little tiring, but totally doable. Although the Birads 5 has the higher possibility of malignancy, there have been women here, who have still received a B9 result. Just know that whatever the outcome, you'll be in good hands and you can come here at any time for support and to ask questions, if you need to.  I know the waiting is brutal, we all agree that it's the worst, but try to keep yourself busy. The stress can make you ill and it certainly won't change the outcome. Let us know how you're getting on! Hugs to you!

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2015 07:40AM - edited Apr 1, 2015 07:46AM by Ariom Hi farmerlucy, thank you! Hello janimil, don't cry, it is very fixable! I know just how you're feeling, I was so disappointed when I discovered I had this shelf under my arm and it zapped and zinged from the cut nerves. I put up with it for about 15 months, hoping it may get better with time. I had spoken to my surgeon about it, very early on and although I don't blame him for it, I wanted it explained. He explained that it is actually flesh, that used to be pulled forward, by the weight of the breast and when they are doing the Mx surgery , they have to stop the incision somewhere, so sometimes that flesh remains and becomes a pouchy, dog ear. I felt just like you, I didn't want more surgery, but I certainly didn't want to put up with this thing either. Initially my surgeon wanted me to go into Hospital and have it done, with a general anesthetic. I hate how the drugs make me feel, so I asked him to do it with a local anesthetic, he wasn't convinced at first, but he finally agreed. He hadn't done this kind of revision without anesthetic before, in fact he said it is rare for women to do this revision at all, but he is really pleased with the result, as I am. In saying this, it isn't for everyone, to have it done this way, but for me, it was very easy, the actual surgery took about 35 minutes. The final result that you saw on breastfree, was pretty good, but now, about a year later, it is barely visible and no discomfort from the nerves, just numb. The revision added abut 7cm or 3" to the original scar and the recovery was actually similar to the Mx, no lifting, or stretching for a few weeks, a little discomfort, but it healed very quickly and I really couldn't be happier with the result. I'd do it again, in a heartbeat! Please feel free to ask anything, PM me, if you like. Just know, if you want to repair it, it can be done at any point, there is no rush! It is very early days for you and things will change over the next few months. I wish you all the best with it.
